parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Fourteen trials recorded substantial numbers of wild bees foraging on sown flowering plants on farmland.
[Statement 2]: Phacelia patches attracted substantial numbers of wild bees in most trials, with 8–35 foraging species recorded.
[Statement 3]: One replicated trial in Greece found phacelia was not attractive to wild bees.
[Statement 4]: Planted perennial leguminous herbs were more attractive to bumblebees in more arable landscapes.
[Statement 5]: Planted lupine patches in Nova Scotia apple orchards enhanced the reproductive success of the bee species Osmia lignaria.
[Statement 6]: One Dutch trial found no increase in bee numbers or species richness at a distance of 50 to 1,500 meters from planted patches.
[Statement 7]: Two German trials found few solitary bees nesting on set-aside fields that were sown with phacelia or clover.
[Statement 8]: Uncropped grassy field margins of 6 meters showed mixed outcomes for wild bee populations.
[Statement 9]: One replicated controlled UK trial found higher wild bee abundance but not higher diversity at field boundaries with uncropped grassy margins.
[Statement 10]: Another trial found higher abundance and diversity of bumblebees within uncropped grassy margins.
[Statement 11]: A third smaller trial found no increases in wild bee populations in uncropped grassy margins.
[Statement 12]: Evidence for the effect of organic arable farming on wild bees is equivocal.
[Statement 13]: Three replicated trials reported higher wild bee abundance on organic farms.
[Statement 14]: One of these trials also reported higher wild bee diversity in organically farmed wheat and adjacent mown fallows.
[Statement 15]: Three other trials found no significant differences in bee numbers, species, or visitation between organic and conventional farms.
[Statement 16]: There is no captured evidence that increasing clover leys enhances wild bee populations.
[Statement 17]: One replicated German trial found that a white clover–grass mix did not attract solitary bees to nest preferentially.
[Statement 18]: A Swiss trial showed that avoiding the use of a mower processor during clover flowering reduces bee injuries and mortality.
[Statement 19]: There is no captured evidence that introducing nest boxes stocked with solitary bees has an effect on farmland wildlife.
[Statement 20]: Rearing or managing solitary bees can increase local megachilid populations up to six-fold in one year when floral resources are plentiful.
[Statement 21]: Parasites and pathogens are issues when rearing or managing solitary bees.
[Statement 22]: Trials using artificial diets for solitary bees have had mixed survival outcomes.
[Statement 23]: Wild bird cover mixtures often benefit invertebrates.
[Statement 24]: Seven UK studies reported that wild bird cover mixtures had a higher abundance or species richness of butterflies and/or bees than other farmland habitats.
[Statement 25]: Four other studies reported mixed or negative effects from wild bird cover mixtures.
[Statement 26]: Invertebrate species showed preferences for specific plants within wild bird cover mixtures.

key: _gpt-5__What is the most cost-effective method for increasing wild bee populations on farmland?
_gpt-5__Is it more effective to connect existing semi-natural habitats or to re-plant native forest to boost bee populations?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: No studies were found that directly tested the effects on wild bee communities of connecting areas of natural or semi-natural habitat for bees.
[Statement 2]: Broader invertebrate evidence shows some colonization of corridors or restored habitat links.
[Statement 3]: The results of invertebrate colonization of corridors or restored links are mixed across taxa.
[Statement 4]: Slow colonization by invertebrates was reported in one case of a restored habitat link.
[Statement 5]: Some wasp groups increased in connected habitat strips.
[Statement 6]: Many ground beetles did not use connected habitat strips effectively.
[Statement 7]: No studies were found that directly tested the effects of re-planting native forest on wild bee communities or populations.
[Statement 8]: Along restored watercourses, bee visitation rates to native flowers were similar to those in remnant sites.
[Statement 9]: Along restored watercourses, the numbers of bees and bee species were similar to those in remnant sites.
[Statement 10]: Bee communities along restored watercourses differed from bee communities in remnant sites.
[Statement 11]: Plant-insect interactions along restored watercourses differed from those in remnant sites.
[Statement 12]: No studies were found demonstrating the effects of increasing or restoring natural or semi-natural habitat in farmed landscapes on bee diversity or abundance in neighbouring farms.

[Statement 1]: The action documents do not report a percentage increase for bumblebee abundance when comparing native wildflower seed mixes with agricultural nectar/pollen mixes.
[Statement 2]: Three replicated trials found that agricultural forage plant mixes, including legumes, attracted greater numbers of bumblebees than a perennial wildflower mix, at least in the first year.
[Statement 3]: One small replicated trial recorded that common long-tongued bumblebee species preferred perennial wildflower seed mix over a mix of annual forage plants.

key: _gpt-5__By what percentage does sowing a native wild flower seed mix on field margins increase bumblebee abundance compared to sowing an agricultural nectar mix?
